value.title: Gradual null safety migration for large Dart projects

content.subtitle: Dart null-safety migration is a 1-2 hour effort for a simple, small package but can be a months-long marathon for a large project. Ideally…

paragraphs.name: 17e0
paragraphs.text: Gradual null safety migration for large Dart projects

paragraphs.name: 43d5
paragraphs.text: Dart null-safety migration is a 1-2 hour effort for a simple, small package but can be a months-long marathon for a large project. Ideally, you want to migrate your project gradually — during the marathon you want to keep your project growable, maintainable, and easy to release.

paragraphs.name: de5e
paragraphs.text: I’ve migrated a large project to null safety and decided to put together steps and tips on how to make the process reliable and efficient, with the hope that it saves you time.
Step 1: Convert to unsound null-safety

paragraphs.name: d440
paragraphs.text: First, migrate your project to unsound null safety.

paragraphs.name: 02dc
paragraphs.text: Start with upgrading your dependencies to null-safe versions. Unsound null safety doesn’t require having all dependencies to be null-safe. However, waiting until all of your upstream dependencies are migrated is strongly recommended since migrating a dependency might force you to revisit migration decisions in your own code. For packages that are mutually dependent, you might be forced to migrate out of order, or to migrate the packages concurrently (many packages that are mutually dependent mostly refer to each other only in tests). Follow the guidance on dart.dev to upgrade as many dependencies as you can before migrating your code.

paragraphs.name: 6ba1
paragraphs.text: Next, update the Dart SDK for your package and mark each non-migrated library as legacy using the following steps:

paragraphs.name: e5e9
paragraphs.text: Make sure that your IDE (VSCode, IntelliJ / Android Studio) has the Dart plugin installed.

paragraphs.name: 13d3
paragraphs.text: Open your package in the IDE and make sure there are no compilation errors.

paragraphs.name: 14cb
paragraphs.text: Update the dart_sdk dependency in the pubspec.yaml file to require the version range: ‘>=2.12.0 <3.0.0’.

The IDE will highlight null-safe related errors in libraries that are not yet null safe. Remove the errors by adding the comment ‘// @dart=2.9’ on the top of each affected file. Add the comment to your main.dart file even if it does not have errors, to keep the app running in unsound mode until you are ready to switch.

paragraphs.name: e63c
paragraphs.text: Verify that all tests pass, and submit the changes to your main branch. If your tests are already null-safe, you will need the command line flag --no-sound-null-safety to suppress null-safe errors.

paragraphs.name: 25c4
paragraphs.text: Make sure that you see Running with unsound null-safety in the console when starting the application.

paragraphs.name: a554
paragraphs.text: Now you are ready to migrate your project to sound null safety one library at a time.

paragraphs.name: 7ab9
paragraphs.text: Step 2: Iterate towards sound null-safety

paragraphs.name: ddf0
paragraphs.text: Choose a library or a set of libraries to migrate.

paragraphs.name: 67ad
paragraphs.text: Pro tip: If the library you selected is large, you might want to break it into smaller libraries before migrating.

paragraphs.name: 035e
paragraphs.text: Use dart pub deps to create a dependency graph of your project. It’s best to migrate packages from the bottom up; start with the leaves in the dependency tree and then iterate up to the root. However, if your project has dependency cycles, this might not be possible and it’s ok not to follow this order.

paragraphs.name: e7e8
paragraphs.text: Migrate the library (or set of libraries) by using the migration tool:

paragraphs.name: d1c0
paragraphs.text: Start the interactive migration tool by running dart migrate --skip-import-check. You may want to cd to the directory with the selected libraries to ease navigation in the tree.

paragraphs.name: a212
paragraphs.text: Deselect everything by deselecting the roots of the file view tree in the left panel. (If interested, vote for a Deselect All button.)

paragraphs.name: 10a3
paragraphs.text: Use Control+F to find the file(s) that you want to migrate.

paragraphs.name: a2e6
paragraphs.text: Select the file(s) and click Apply Migration. There are two options how you can make adjustments: (1) use comments to adjust the tools’s choices before applying migration or (2) use an IDE to evaluate the nullability of fields, parameters, and variables after applying migration.

paragraphs.name: 61e2
paragraphs.text: Open the package in the IDE. Fix errors, and search the files for cases where the tool might be inaccurate (see a list of potential issues below). Make corrections and use lint warnings to interactively clean up upstream and downstream code.

paragraphs.name: b8bc
paragraphs.text: You will not be able to fix two lint errors:

paragraphs.name: 51de
paragraphs.text: import_of_legacy_library_into_null_safe (in migrated libraries)

paragraphs.name: f481
paragraphs.text: avoid_redundant_argument_values (in legacy libraries)

paragraphs.name: 5cc1
paragraphs.text: For now, disable these errors with comments. You’ll clean these up later, after migration is done.

paragraphs.name: c35e
paragraphs.text: What potential tool inaccuracies to watch for:

paragraphs.name: 5ee1
paragraphs.text: Added types dynamic or num. Most likely you know which specific type should be used instead.

paragraphs.name: e8e1
paragraphs.text: In most cases, bool? can become bool with a default value.

paragraphs.name: 7bd2
paragraphs.text: Type casts (search for ‘ as ‘) might mean that the tool didn’t add a generic type parameter. After adding it, a lint indicates that the cast has become unnecessary and can be removed.
In some cases, the tool makes the bound on a generic parameter nullable when it might be better to make it non-nullable (search for ?> and ?,).

paragraphs.name: ce36
paragraphs.text: The tool might make things nullable that could be better expressed using late or late final, or that could be refactored to allow initialization in the constructor’s initializer list. (If interested, vote for a lint.)

paragraphs.name: 6f8a
paragraphs.text: Using a null-assert operation ! without first checking for a null value might mean that the variable or parameter should actually be non-nullable. (If interested, vote for a lint.)

paragraphs.name: 0d5a
paragraphs.text: The tool adds casting for collections in the form collection as Iterable<TheType>. Sometimes, this change just makes a cast explicit that was already implicit. However, in other cases, these casts might introduce runtime errors because of mismatches in the nullability of the generic arguments. If in doubt, consider replacing the cast with an explicit per element conversion (for example, collection.cast<TheType>()), or consider using the whereNotNull extension method from package:collection.

paragraphs.name: 75ef
paragraphs.text: If a variable, field, or parameter is nullable, but the nullability is used only in the tests, perhaps the code should be refactored to remove nullability for that identifier.

paragraphs.name: 2c4b
paragraphs.text: (Thanks to Kenzie Davisson, who helped me identify these cases.)

paragraphs.name: 78f7
paragraphs.text: Step 3: Cleanup

paragraphs.name: 1a31
paragraphs.text: After migrating all of your libraries, do some final cleanup:

paragraphs.name: a09d
paragraphs.text: Clean up the disabling comments for the lints.
Upgrade the remaining dependencies to null safe versions.

paragraphs.name: 79b1
paragraphs.text: Ensure that there are no `//@dart = 2.9` comments remaining in your app. At this point, you should see Running with sound null-safety in the console when starting the app. If you don’t see this, you either have libraries that aren’t yet migrated (search for `// @dart = 2.9`), or a dependency that has not been migrated.

paragraphs.name: a98f
paragraphs.text: Ensure that the app still runs correctly and that the tests pass. Since sound mode enables stronger runtime guarantees, it’s possible (though unlikely) that you will see new runtime errors which you need to fix when you enable sound null safety. Usually this is the result of casting a nullable collection (like List<int?>) to a non-nullable collection type (like List<int>).

paragraphs.name: 8ab9
paragraphs.text: Have a happy migration!
